'''Ralph Lauren Corporation''' ({{NYSE|RL}}) is an American corporation producing mid-range to luxury fashion products. They are known for the clothing, marketing and distribution of products in four categories: apparel, home, accessories, and fragrances. The Company's brands include Polo Ralph Lauren, Ralph Lauren Collection, Lauren Ralph Lauren, Double RL, Ralph Lauren Childrenswear, Denim & Supply Ralph Lauren, Chaps, and Club Monaco. Ralph Lauren Corporation is an American, publicly traded holding company headquartered in New York City, and founded in 1967 by American [[fashion designer]] [[Ralph Lauren]].
==History== [[File:Polo Ralph Lauren logo.png|thumb|left|Polo Ralph Lauren – the flagship brand of the company.]] The Ralph Lauren Corporation started in 1967 with men's ties. At 28 years-old, Lauren worked for the tie manufacturer, Beau Brummell. He persuaded the company's president to let him start his own line. Drawing on his interests in sports, Lauren named his first full line of menswear ‘Polo’ in 1968. He worked out of a single "drawer" from a showroom in the [[Empire State Building]] and made deliveries to stores himself.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/ralph-lauren-the-patriarch-of-fashions-rise-from-rag-trader-to-american-royalty-a6674416.html |title = Ralph Lauren: The patriarch of fashion's rise from rag-trader to American royalty |publisher = The Independent |date= 2015-09-30 |accessdate= 2016-11-03}}</ref>
By 1969, the [[Manhattan]] department store [[Bloomingdale's]] sold Lauren's men line exclusively. It was the first time that Bloomingdale's had given a designer his own in-store shop. In 1971, Ralph Lauren Corporation launched a line of tailored shirts for women, which introduced the Polo player emblem, appearing on the shirt cuff. The first full women's collection was launched the following year.<ref name="Ralph Lauren Through the Years">{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/09/29/business/Ralph-Lauren-career.html?_r=0 |title = Ralph Lauren Through the Years |publisher = The New York Times |accessdate= 2016-11-03}}</ref>
1972 marked the opening of Ralph Lauren's store on Rodeo Drive in [[Beverly Hills, California]], his first freestanding store.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ralph Lauren Through the Years |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/09/29/business/Ralph-Lauren-career.html |website=The New York Times |publisher=nytimes |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> In 1977 Ralph Lauren Corporation introduced a signature cotton mesh Polo shirt in various colours. Featuring the polo player logo on the chest, the shirt became emblematic of the preppy look—one of Lauren's signature style.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
In 1974, Ralph Lauren outfitted the male cast of ''[[The Great Gatsby]]'' in costumes chosen from his Polo line - a 1920s-style series of men's suits and sweaters, except for the pink suit which Lauren designed especially for [[Robert Redford]]’s ''[[Jay Gatsby]]''. In 1977, [[Diane Keaton]] and [[Woody Allen]] wore Lauren's clothes in the Oscar-winning film, ''[[Annie Hall]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/exploring-the-world-of-fashion-in-film-763147.html|title = Exploring the world of fashion in film |publisher = The Independent |date=1987-11-26 |accessdate= 2016-11-03}}</ref>
In 1978, the first Ralph Lauren fragrances, produced by Warner-Lauren, Ltd were launched at Bloomingdale's. Lauren for women, and Polo the men's cologne. This was the first time that a designer introduced two fragrances – one for men and one for women – simultaneously.<ref name="Ralph Lauren Through the Years"/>
The company entered the European market, and went international, in 1981 with the opening of the first freestanding store in [[Bond Street|New Bond Street]] in the [[West End of London]], England. Lauren opened his first flagship in the Rhinelander mansion, on Madison Avenue and 72nd Street in New York City in 1986.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://fortune.com/1996/11/11/ralph-lauren-emperor-cover/ |title = Ralph Lauren: The emperor has clothes |publisher = Fortune |date=1996-11-26 |accessdate= 2016-11-07}}</ref> On June 12, 1997, the company becomes a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/ralph-lauren-corp-11816-8646 |title = RALPH LAUREN CORP (RL) IPO |publisher = Nasdaq |accessdate= 2016-11-07}}</ref>
The 98-seat restaurant, RL, opened in March 1999 in a newly constructed building adjacent to the largest Ralph Lauren store at the corner of Chicago and Michigan Avenues. It was followed by the opening of two additional restaurants – Ralph's at 173 Boulevard Saint Germain Paris store in 2010 and The Polo Bar at Polo's store in New York in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/10/dining/a-ralph-lauren-restaurant-the-polo-bar-comes-to-new-york.html?_r=0 |title = Ralph Lauren Creates His Clubhouse |publisher = New York Times |date=2014-12-09 |accessdate= 2016-11-07}}</ref>
The company launched its website and online shop in 2000 as polo.com by RL Media (a cooperation between Ralph Lauren and NBC). In 2007, Ralph Lauren Corporation acquired the NBC share of RL Media and the website was relaunched as ralphlauren.com. In September 2015, it was announced that [[Stefan Larsson (businessman)|Stefan Larsson]] would replace the company's founder, Ralph Lauren, as CEO in November. Lauren will stay on as executive chairman and chief creative officer.<ref name=NYtimes>{{cite news|last1=TABUCHI|first1=HIROKO|last2=FRIEDMAN|first2=VANESSA|title=Ralph Lauren, Creator of Fashion Empire, Is Stepping Down as C.E.O.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/business/ralph-lauren-creator-of-fashion-empire-steps-down-as-ceo.html|accessdate=30 September 2015|work=NY Times|date=29 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/style/mens-fashion/news/a38385/ralph-lauren-steps-down-ceo/|title=End of an Era: Ralph Lauren Is Stepping Down as CEO of His Company|date=2015-09-29|website=Esquire|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref>
In February 2017 it was announced that Larsson had agreed to leave his position as CEO effective May 1, 2017 due to differences with Lauren.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/laurengensler/2017/02/02/ralph-lauren-stefan-larsson-ceo-departure/#19fee10d18c4|title=Ralph Lauren CEO To Depart Over 'Different Views' With Founder, Shares Tumble|last=Gensler|first=Lauren|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2017-02-02}}</ref> On May 17, 2017, Ralph Lauren named [[Patrice Louvet]] President and [[Chief Executive Officer]].<ref name=ft-badkar>{{cite news |last=Badkar |first=Mamta |date=May 18, 2017 |title=Ralph Lauren adjusted earnings top estimates as it bridles discounts |url=https://www.ft.com/content/a46757ce-7067-3999-8cb7-28b7bb7db1c7 | work=[[Financial Times]] |location=United Kingdom |access-date=May 18, 2017}}</ref> Louvet most recently served as Group President, Global Beauty at [[Procter & Gamble]] (P&G).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ralphlauren-moves-ceo-idUSKCN18D1H7 Reuters]</ref> He took over on July 17, 2017.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-17/ralph-lauren-names-p-g-veteran-patrice-louvet-as-its-next-chief Bloomberg]</ref><ref>[http://fortune.com/2017/05/17/ralph-lauren-ceo-patrice-louvet/ Fortune]</ref><ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/ralph-lauren-taps-procter-gamble-executive-as-its-next-ceo-1495026766 The Wall Street Journal]</ref>
==Brands== [[File:Ralph Lauren wool scarf.jpg|thumb|A woolen Polo Ralph Lauren scarf]] * '''Ralph Lauren Women's Collection and Ralph Lauren Purple Label:''' Ralph Lauren Collection for women, launched in 1971, ranges from handmade evening gowns to sportswear. Launched in 1994, Ralph Lauren Purple Label<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.mrporter.com/journal/journal_issue5/2 |title =BEHIND THE BRAND: RALPH LAUREN |publisher = Mr Porter |date= 2011-03-23 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> for men offers suiting, custom tailored made-to-measure suits and sportswear, as well as benchmade footwear and made-to-order dress furnishings, accessories, and luggage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/womens-style/32447/ralph-lauren-the-man-who-dresses-america.html |title =Ralph Lauren: the man who dresses America |publisher = The Telegraph |date= 2014-05-02 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Ralph Lauren Watches and Fine Jewelry:''' In 2009 Ralph Lauren, together with luxury group Compagnie Financière Richemont SA, launched a collection of timepieces through the Ralph Lauren Watch & Jewelry Co. In 2010, the Ralph Lauren Watch & Jewelry Co. also introduced collections of jewelry.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ralph-lauren-is-pushing-higher-into-luxury-with-new-stores-accessories-1407971396 |title =Ralph Lauren Is Pushing Higher Into Luxury With New Stores, Accessories |publisher = The Wall Street Journal |date= 2014-08-13 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Polo Ralph Lauren:''' Men’s Polo, Ralph Lauren’s first complete line of sportswear and tailored clothing launched in 1967. In 2014, Women’s Polo was launched.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mrporter.com/journal/journal_issue45/4 |title = THE INTRO: RALPH LAUREN |publisher = Mr Porter |date= 2012-01-03 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Polo Sport:''' Polo Sport launched in 1992, a line of activewear for sports and fitness. In 2014, Ralph Lauren debuted the PoloTech Shirt, which featured smart fabric technology that supposedly "captures robust biometrics from the wearer".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gq.com/story/polo-sport-1992-snow-beach-jacket-buy |title = This 1992 Polo Sport Jacket Will Make You a Style God |publisher = GQ |date= 2016-10-26 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Double RL:''' Founded in 1993 and named after Ralph Lauren and his wife Ricky's “RRL” ranch in Colorado, RRL offers men a mix of selvage denim, vintage apparel, sportswear and accessories, with roots in workwear and military gear.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ralphlauren.com/de/en/magazine/east-meets-west |title = EAST MEETS WEST |publisher = Ralph Lauren |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Lauren Ralph Lauren:''' Lauren for Women launched in 1996, offering sportswear, denim, dresses, activewear, and accessories and footwear at a cheaper price point. Lauren for Men offers men's tailored clothing, including suits, sport coats, dress shirts, dress pants, tuxedos, topcoats, and ties at a cheaper price point.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/Ki-Le/Lauren-Ralph.html |title = Ralph Lauren - Fashion Designer |publisher = Fashion Encyclopedia |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> This brand generally slots above Chaps in price, but below Polo Ralph Lauren. * '''Ralph by Ralph Lauren:''' Launched in 1994, Ralph by Ralph Lauren offers suit separates, sport coats, vests, and topcoats.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/24/business/goldman-buys-28-stake-in-ralph-lauren-s-empire.html |title = Goldman Buys 28% Stake In Ralph Lauren's Empire |publisher = The New York Times |date= 1994-08-24 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Polo Golf and RLX Golf:''' Polo Golf launched in 1990 and RLX Golf launched in 1998.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.ajga.org/2008Polo/polo.asp |title = About Our Premier Partner... Polo Ralph Lauren |publisher = ajga.org |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Pink Pony:''' Established in 2000, a percentage of sales from all Pink Pony products benefit the Pink Pony Fund and other major cancer charities around the world. Pink Pony primarily consists of women's sportswear and accessories. All Pink Pony items feature a pink Polo Player.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://global.ralphlauren.com/en-us/About/Philanthropy/Pages/pink_pony.aspx??ab=int_092712_MOODBANNER_PINKPONY_LEARNMORE |title = Pink Money Fund |publisher = Ralph Lauren |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Polo Ralph Lauren Children:''' Items include polo knit shirts and cashmere cable sweaters.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.biography.com/people/ralph-lauren-9374814 |title = Ralph Lauren Biography |publisher = BIO |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Denim & Supply Ralph Lauren:''' The Denim & Supply Ralph Lauren line launched in 2011, inspired by the warehouse and artist communities of Brooklyn, New York and authentic style found in the music festival scene.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.luxurydaily.com/ralph-lauren-goes-back-to-basics-with-new-denim-supply-brand/ |title = Ralph Lauren goes back to basics with new Denim & Supply brand |publisher = Luxury Daily |date= 2011-08-12 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Chaps:''' A mid-range brand featuring casual sportswear, workday, and dresses.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://fortune.com/2014/05/09/what-will-happen-to-ralph-lauren-without-ralph/ |title = What will happen to Ralph Lauren without Ralph? |publisher = Fortune |date= 2014-05-09 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> The Chaps brand is available primarily at [[Kohl's]] and [[Belk]] stores, and is priced to compete with [[PVH (company)|PVH]]'s [[Izod]] brand. * '''Club Monaco:''' Club Monaco designs and markets its own clothing and accessories for men and women.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/02/business/ralph-lauren-buying-casual-clothing-retailer.html |title =Ralph Lauren Buying Casual Clothing Retailer |publisher = The New York Times |date= 1999-03-02 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''American Living:''' Ralph Lauren launched American Living for men and women in 2008, a mid-range lifestyle brand created exclusively for [[JCPenney]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.cnbc.com/id/23273084 |title =JC Penney And Ralph Lauren Take Chance With "American Living" |publisher = CNBC |date= 2008-02-21|accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> This line was comparable to the Chaps line, but was marketed as a more exclusive line, unlike Chaps which is sold at multiple retailers. This line was discontinued in 2012 due to poor sales. A different American Living line is now sold at [[Macy's]]; the current American Living line only includes women's clothing. * '''Ralph Lauren Home and Paint:''' Ralph Lauren Home, the first complete home collection from an American clothing designer, makes its debut in 1983 with home furnishings and accessories. Ralph Lauren Home includes furniture, bed and bath linens, china, crystal, silver, decorative accessories and gifts, as well as lighting, fabric, wallcovering, and floorcovering. Ralph Lauren launched Paint in 1995, now with over 400 palettes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ralph-lauren-home-announces-a-new-license-agreement-with-ici-paints-glidden-company-73595737.html |title = Ralph Lauren Home Announces a New License Agreement With ICI Paints' Glidden Company |publisher = PR News Wire |date= 2000-06-15 |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Fragrance:''' In 1978, Ralph Lauren launched his first fragrances: Lauren for women and Polo for men. Originally produced by Warner-Lauren, Ltd, L’Oréal now produces the Ralph Lauren Fragrances for men and women, including World of Polo (Polo, Polo Blue, Polo Black, Polo Red), Ralph Lauren Romance, Midnight Romance and the Big Pony Collections For Women and For Men.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.loreal.com/brand/l%E2%80%99or%C3%A9al-luxe/ralph-lauren |title = RALPH LAUREN |publisher = L’Oreal |accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref> * '''Ralph Lauren Restaurants:''' RL Restaurant opened in 1999, adjacent to the Ralph Lauren Chicago store on Michigan Avenue. In 2010, Ralph's was opened in the courtyard and converted stables at 173 Boulevard Saint Germain Paris flagship store. In August 2014, Ralph's Coffee opened on the second floor of the Polo Flagship store in New York City. The Polo Bar, adjacent to the New York City Polo Flagship store, opened in January 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/09/29/business/Ralph-Lauren-career.html |title = Ralph Lauren Through the Years |publisher = The New York Times|accessdate= 2016-11-15}}</ref>
==Stores== [[File:Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo Mansion 002.JPG|right|thumb|The Ralph Lauren flagship store occupying the [[Rhinelander Mansion]] on [[Madison Avenue]] in New York City]] [[File:Lauren 888 Mad Av 72 St sunny jeh.jpg|thumb|Ralph Lauren store on [[Madison Avenue]] in New York City]] The Company ended Fiscal 2016 with 493 directly operated stores: 144 Ralph Lauren stores, 77 Club Monaco stores and 272 Polo factory stores. The Company also operated 583 concession shop locations worldwide at the end of the year.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160204005731/en/Ralph-Lauren-Reports-Quarter-Fiscal-2016-Results| title= Ralph Lauren Reports Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Results| publisher=Business Wire| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Smith & Caughey's Queen Street Ralph Lauren children 2013.jpg|thumb|Children's clothing at department store [[Smith & Caughey's]] [[Queen Street, Auckland|Queen Street]] in [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]]]
In addition to Company-operated locations, international licensing partners operated 93 Ralph Lauren stores and 42 dedicated shops, as well as 133 [[Club Monaco]] stores and shops at the end of Fiscal 2016.
Ralph Lauren operates its representative flagship stores in New York City on [[Madison Avenue]] – for menswear in the former [[Rhinelander Mansion]], and for womenswear and home in another structure, across the street, which opened in 2010. The company also manages flagships, for retailing Ralph Lauren collections, in [[Chicago]], [[Manhasset, New York|Manhasset]], [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]] (USA), [[London]], [[Milan]], [[Tokyo]], [[Moscow]], and [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://flagships.ralphlauren.com/?ab=SLLP_Banner_Explore| title=Our Global Flagships| publisher=Ralph Lauren Media, LLC| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
==Sports sponsorships== ===USTA===
In 2005, The United States Tennis Association selects Ralph Lauren Corporation as the official apparel sponsor for the [[US Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]]. As part of the partnership, all on-court ball persons and officials will be dressed in specially-designed Ralph Lauren apparel. This is Polo's first tennis sponsorship.<ref>{{cite press release| title=Polo and the USTA Sign Four-Year Global US Open Partnership| url=http://www.pambianconews.com/2005/03/14/polo-and-the-usta-sign-four-year-global-us-open-partnership-12037/| date=March 14, 2005| work=Pambianco News| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
===Wimbledon===
In 2006, Ralph Lauren Corporation became the official outfitter of [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]. Lauren is the first designer in the tennis tournament’s history to be chosen to create uniforms for all on-court officials.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]]| title=Ralph Lauren to Outfit Players at Wimbledon |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/18/sports/sp-wimbywhites18 |date=June 18, 2006 |page=D4 |quote=Polo Ralph Lauren Corp. will become the first external company in 129 years to outfit the tournament's on-court officials, who will exchange their green polyester grass-blending jackets for smart navy blue ones. In the past, Wimbledon has done its own design of officials' uniforms.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Wimbledon Fashion by Polo Ralph Lauren {{!}} Polo Shirts {{!}} Tee Shirts {{!}} Track Tops {{!}} Ball Boy Tops {{!}} Accessories|url = http://shop.wimbledon.com/stores/wimbledon/en/c/ralph-lauren|website = shop.wimbledon.com|access-date = 2016-02-13}}</ref>
===U.S. Olympic Team=== Ralph Lauren Corporation is the exclusive Official Parade Outfitter for the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Teams, with the right to manufacture, distribute, advertise, promote, and sell products in the U.S. which replicate the Parade Outfits and associated leisure wear. The Company has established a partnership with athletes serving as brand ambassadors and as the faces of the advertising, marketing, and public relations campaigns.<ref name=Dodes>{{cite news| title=Polo to Outfit U.S. Team For the Beijing Olympics| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120752759769693767| date=April 7, 2008| work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| last1=Dodes| first1=Rachel| last2=Kang| first2=Stephanie| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name=TorStar>{{cite news| title=Roots no longer outfitting Olympic teams, co-founder says| first=Michelle| last=McQuigge| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2008/04/07/roots_no_longer_outfitting_olympic_teams_cofounder_says.html| agency=[[The Canadian Press]]| date=April 8, 2008| work=[[Toronto Star]]| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
Ralph Lauren Corporation partners with the United States Olympic Committee to become an Official Outfitter of the U.S. Olympic Team, for the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, 2012 Summer Olympics in London, 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi and 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio.<ref name=Pells>{{cite news| title=US team to wear Ralph Lauren again at Olympic ceremonies| url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/sports/2009409534_apolyusuniforms.html| agency=Associated Press| first=Eddie| last=Pells| work=[[The Seattle Times]]| date=July 2, 2009| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
Ralph Lauren designs the official Opening Ceremony and Closing Ceremony parade outfits for the U.S. teams in addition to an assortment of village-wear apparel and accessories.<ref>{{citation|title=All the Designer Outfits the Olympians Will Be Wearing Tonight |author=Colleen KRATOFIL|date=August 5, 2016|work=People|url=http://people.com/style/olympics-2016-opening-ceremony-athlete-style-designers/}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== In 1989, it co-Founded the Nina Hyde Center for Breast Cancer Research at [[Georgetown University Hospital]] in [[Washington D.C.]] in memory of the late Post fashion correspondent.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/obituaries/nina-hyde-57-a-fashion-editor-who-became-a-pacesetter-is-dead.html|title=Nina Hyde, 57, a Fashion Editor Who Became a Pacesetter, Is Dead |work= The New York Times |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In 1994, Ralph Lauren acted as chairman and creates the name and symbol for Fashion Targets Breast Cancer, a charitable initiative of the CFDA that marshals the goodwill and services of the fashion industry to raise public awareness and funds for breast cancer internationally.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/wellbeing/health-advice/ralph-laurens-breast-cancer-campaign-turns-20-years-old/|title=Ralph Lauren’s breast cancer campaign turns 20 years old |work= The Telegraph |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In 2000, Ralph Lauren Corporation launched its Volunteer Program, which energises employees and creates meaningful connections with the communities in which they work.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://global.ralphlauren.com/en-gb/About/Philanthropy/Pages/polo_volunteer.aspx?|title=Ralph Lauren Volunteer Program |work= Ralph Lauren |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
On September 15, 2000, Ralph Lauren Corporation launched the Pink Pony Campaign, a national initiative to reduce disparities in cancer care by raising awareness as well as enhancing prevention, screening, and treatment in poor and underserved communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fashiontimes.com/articles/12319/20141006/ralph-laurens-pink-pony-fund-initiative-launches.htm|title=Ralph Lauren's Pink Pony Fund Initiative Launches|work=The Fashion Times|accessdate=2016-10-03}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 2001, the Polo Ralph Lauren Foundation established the American Heroes Fund following September 11 to allow Polo's 10,000 employees worldwide, as well as their customers, the opportunity to participate in the relief effort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fashioncapital.co.uk/industry/news/326-learning/12385-Ralph-Lauren-Timeline|title=Ralph Lauren Timeline|work=The Fashion Capital|accessdate=2016-10-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005084450/http://www.fashioncapital.co.uk/industry/news/326-learning/12385-Ralph-Lauren-Timeline|archivedate=October 5, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2003, Ralph Lauren established the Ralph Lauren Center for Cancer Care and Prevention in Harlem. The Center is a collaboration between Ralph Lauren, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, and North General Hospital in Harlem, New York City.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/21/nyregion/cancer-center-to-be-establishes-in-harlem.html|title=Cancer Center to Be Establishes in Harlem|work= The New York Times |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In 2004, the Polo Fashion School was established, in which company executives work with inner-city youth to offer insights into the fashion business.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://global.ralphlauren.com/en-gb/About/Philanthropy/Pages/adopt_a_school.aspx|title=Polo Fashion School|work= Ralph Lauren |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
Established in 2006, the Polo Jeans G.I.V.E. (Get Involved Volunteer Exceed) campaign was created to inspire and encourage community service through volunteerism by supporting the efforts of dedicated volunteers and their causes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treehugger.com/sustainable-product-design/ralph-lauren-insulates-habitat-for-humanity-homes.html|title=Ralph Lauren Insulates Habitat for Humanity Homes|work= The Tree Hugger|accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In 2008, the Star-Spangled Banner, the original 1813 flag that inspired Francis Scott Key to write the National Anthem, was preserved by a $10 million contribution to Save America's Treasures from Polo Ralph Lauren in 1998. The flag was then unveiled on Wednesday, November 19, 2008 in a new gallery at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History, in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://americanhistory.si.edu/press/releases/smithsonians-star-spangled-banner-undergo-three-year-conservation|title=Smithsonian's Star-Spangled Banner to Undergo Three-Year Conservation|work=American History |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In July 2013, Ralph Lauren Corporation announced its commitment to restore the elite [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in Paris, one of the most influential art schools in France.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.com/969806/ralph-lauren-restores-lecole-de-beaux-arts/|title=Ralph Lauren Restores the Amphitheater of the École des Beaux-Arts|work= Vogue |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
In 2014, Ralph Lauren Corporation partnered with [[The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust]], the largest and most comprehensive cancer center in [[Europe]], to develop a world-class breast cancer research facility. In 2016, Ralph Lauren Corporation opened the Royal Marsden Ralph Lauren Center for Breast Cancer Research.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.royalmarsden.nhs.uk/our-research/our-research-facilities/ralph-lauren-centre-breast-cancer-research |title=The Ralph Lauren Centre for Breast Cancer Research|work= The NHS |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
==Controversy== ===Levi Strauss lawsuit=== [[Levi Strauss & Co.]] filed a lawsuit against [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] and the RL Corporation in July 2007 for [[trademark infringement]]. It alleged that the separate retailers used Levi's trademarked pocket design of connected arches in the design of some of their respective products.<ref name="levi">{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/07/26/news/companies/levis_lawsuit/index.htm| title=Levi's says Abercrombie pick pocketed design |accessdate=June 22, 2015 |work=CNN |date=July 26, 2007}}</ref>
===South African Polo trademark issues=== The Polo brand sold in [[South Africa]] is not affiliated with the Ralph Lauren [[brand]]. An independent South African company [[trademark]]ed the Polo name and logo in South Africa.<ref name=Wheeldon>{{cite web |url=http://www.buildingipvalue.com/06MENA/300_302.htm |title=South Africa: Major developments in IP law |work=IP Value |first=Ron |last=Wheeldon |accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Power>{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/lifestyle/2014/03/10/polo-sa-not-polo-ralph-lauren |title=Polo SA not Polo Ralph Lauren |first=Megan |last=Power |date=10 March 2014 |work=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] |location=[[Johannesburg]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref>
===Filippa Hamilton photo controversy=== In 2009, Ralph Lauren apologized for digitally retouching a photograph of model [[Filippa Hamilton]] to make her look thinner.<ref name=Mail1>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1219046/Ralph-Lauren-digitally-retouches-slender-model-make-look-THINNER.html |title=Ralph Lauren apologizes for digitally retouching slender model to make her head look bigger than her waist |date=October 10, 2009 |work=[[Daily Mail]] |location=UK |accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> Hamilton also claims that she was fired by Ralph Lauren a few days later.<ref name=Huff>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/10/14/filippa-hamilton-ralph-la_n_320396.html| title=Filippa Hamilton, Ralph Lauren's Retouched Model: I Was Fired For Being Too Fat| work=[[The Huffington Post]]| accessdate=June 22, 2015| date=March 18, 2010}}</ref> Another model's photo was also digitally retouched<ref name=Mail2>{{cite news| title=Second Ralph Lauren model in Photoshop row as she's airbrushed to become impossibly skinny| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1221675/Ralph-Lauren-new-photoshop-row-SECOND-image-model-airbrushed-make-head-larger-waist-emerges.html| work=Daily Mail| accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref> adding to the row of models.

[[EyeSteelFilm]] | country = Canada | language = English | budget = }} '''''RiP!: A Remix Manifesto''''' is a 2008 [[open-source film|open-source]] documentary film about "the changing concept of [[copyright]]"Kirsner, Scott. [http://cinematech.blogspot.com/2007/10/cinematech-filmmaker-q-brett-gaylor-of.html "CinemaTech Filmmaker Q&A: Brett Gaylor of Open Source Cinema".]Sinnott, Shane. "[http://www.montrealmirror.com/2007/032907/load.html The Load-Down] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630225243/http://www.montrealmirror.com/2007/032907/load.html |date=30 June 2007 }}", ''[[Montreal Mirror]]'', 2007-03-29. Accessed 2008-06-30 directed by [[Brett Gaylor]].[https://www.wired.com/underwire/2009/05/brett-gaylor-talks-rip-remix-manifesto/ brett-gaylor-talks-rip-remix-manifesto] on [[wired.com]] (2009) Created over a period of six years, the documentary film features the collaborative remix work of hundreds of people who have contributed to the [[Open Source Cinema]] website, helping to create the "world's first [[open source]] documentary" as Gaylor put it. The project's [[working title]] was ''Basement Tapes'',[https://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-429453083182656636 CinemaTech interview with Brett Gaylor about Open Source Cinema project] at [[Google Videos]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111205075005/https://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-429453083182656636 |date=5 December 2011 }} (referring to [[The Basement Tapes|the album of the same name]]) but it was renamed ''RiP!: A Remix Manifesto'' prior to theatrical release. Gaylor encourages more people to create their own remixes from this movie,[https://web.archive.org/web/20160826014720/http://www.documentary.org/content/copyright-or-copywrong-rip-challenges-intellectual-property-rights Copyright or Copywrong?: 'RiP' Challenges Intellectual Property Rights] By Marc Glassman on documentary.org (archived) using media available from the Open Source Cinema website, or other websites like [[YouTube]], [[Flickr]], [[Hulu]], or [[MySpace]]. ==Background== Gaylor traveled the world to find like-minded people who would help him draft the "Remixer's Manifesto" that makes up the structure of his open source documentary. The manifesto reads as follows: {{quote| #Culture always builds on the past. #The past always tries to control the future. #Our future is becoming less free. #To build free societies you must limit the control of the past|Brett Gaylor in Rip! A Remix Manifesto{{cite web|last=Hardy |first=Steve |url=http://creativegeneralist.com/2009/03/rip-a-remix-manifesto/ |title=Rip! A Remix Manifesto |website=Creative Generalist |date=8 March 2009 |accessdate=2014-05-19}}}} To further his point, Gaylor separates the corporations from the [[public domain]], defining the former using so-called "[[Copy right|CopyRIGHT]]," and the latter, which represents the free exchange of ideas, as "[[Copyleft|CopyLEFT]]."{{cite web|last=Gelevan |first=Douglas |url=http://dgelevan.wordpress.com/2010/04/02/getting-ripped-brett-gaylors-rip-a-remix-manifesto-a-case-study/ |title=Getting 'RiP'ped – Brett Gaylor's RiP: A Remix Manifesto |website=Douglas Gelevan Reports |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-05-19}} Gaylor and Gillis are clearly on the side of the Copyleft, promoting the free flow and growth of creativity and ideas. To enable a free [[Remix culture|remixing culture]] also with his film, he released RiP! under the [[CC BY-NC-SA]] 3.0[https://wiki.creativecommons.org/wiki/Case_Studies/RIP:_A_Remix_Manifesto IP:_A_Remix_Manifesto] on creativecommons.org [[Creative Commons license]]. ==Participants== The documentary is particularly interested in the [[non liquet|legal]] [[wikt:grey area|grey area]] of remixing existing works. The film features appearances by: * Gregg Gillis (better known as [[Girl Talk (musician)|Girl Talk]]) an American musician specializing in [[Mashup (music)|mashup]]-style remixes, which often use a dozen or more unauthorized samples from different songs to create an entirely new track. Gillis' 2006 album Night Ripper had potentially 300 copyright infringements and carried a maximum financial liability penalty of around $45 million. To some he is considered a creative rebel of a mash-up artist, while others deem his work pure copyright infringement.{{cite news |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/arts/story.html?id=e88e2492-f6cb-4059-ba2a-17e79ed736b7 |title=RiP: A Remix Manifesto: review |website=Canada.com |date=16 October 2008 |accessdate=2014-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140926143114/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/arts/story.html?id=e88e2492-f6cb-4059-ba2a-17e79ed736b7 |archivedate=26 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }} * [[Lawrence Lessig]], an American [[Academia|academic]] and political activist, and a professor of law at [[Harvard Law School]] and founder of the [[Stanford Center for Internet and Society|Center for Internet and Society]]. He is best known as a proponent of reduced legal restrictions on [[copyright]], trademark, and [[radio frequency|radio frequency spectrum]], particularly in technology applications. He was previously a professor of law at Stanford Law School. Gaylor discusses the legal protection of fair use with Lessig to determine the ability to produce the film. * [[Cory Doctorow]], a Canadian blogger, journalist and science fiction author. Doctorow is co-editor of the blog [[Boing Boing]] and is an activist in favor of reforming [[copyright]] laws. He is a proponent of the [[Creative Commons]] organization, using some of their licenses for his books. Common themes in his work include [[digital rights management]] and [[file sharing]]. In the film, Doctorow states, "Technology giveth, technology taketh away.” * [[Gilberto Gil]], the Brazilian musician and former Minister of Cultural Affairs who initiated pioneering programs in [[Brazil]] through a partnership with [[Creative Commons]]. As Minister, he sponsored a program called Culture Points, which gives [[Grant (money)|grants]] to provide music technology and education to people living in poor areas of the country's cities.{{cite news |first=Larry |last=Rohter |authorlink=Larry Rohter |title=Gilberto Gil and the politics of music |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/03/12/news/gil.php |work=[[International Herald Tribune]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |location=[[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]], [[Brazil]] |date=12 March 2007 |accessdate=2008-03-16 }} * [[Dan O'Neill]], an underground cartoonist and founder of the [[Air Pirates]], a group which was famously sued by [[The Walt Disney Company]] for copyright infringement. * [[Jammie Thomas]], the single mom successfully sued by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) at the [[Capitol v. Thomas]] case for Thomas' illegal downloading. The single mother, who made US$36,000 a year, was ordered to pay US$222,220 in damages for making 24 songs available for download on the [[Kazaa]] [[file sharing network]]. ==Other topics== The 1710 [[Statute of Anne]] gave authors the exclusive rights to their works. The documentary was able to be made and distributed due to the part of [[Copyright law of the United States|copyright law]] deemed [[fair use]], the ability to use copyrighted works to prove a point. Fair use allows for [[Freedom of speech|free speech]]. Due to the fact that Gaylor tries to prove a point about copyright law and the rights of artists in his film, he is legally allowed to use examples to get his point across. He uses remixed music in the film to give examples of what would be considered illegal. The film also discusses the consequences of illegal downloading and [[copyright infringement]]. The [[Capitol Records, Inc. v. Thomas-Rasset]]t case was the first file-sharing copyright infringement lawsuit in the United States to be brought in front of a jury by [[major record labels]]. ==Festivals and awards== ''RiP!: A Remix Manifesto'' made its international debut at the IDFA ([[International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam]]) in November 2008.[https://web.archive.org/web/20081207072305/http://www.idfa.nl/en/news/latestnews/winners-idfa-2008-announced.aspx "winners at the IDFA festival 2008"]. Archived from the [http://www.idfa.nl/en/news/latestnews/winners-idfa-2008-announced.aspx original] 2008-12-07. It won the festival's Audience Award. The film made its US debut at the [[South by Southwest]] festival on 15 March 2009.{{cite web |title=SXSW Interactive at the Movies |url=http://sxsw.com/node/1187 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120112056/http://sxsw.com/node/1187 |archivedate=20 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The Canadian news-magazine ''[[Macleans]]'' called the movie as "a dazzling frontal assault on how corporate culture is using copyright law to muzzle freedom of expression."{{cite magazine|last=Johnson |first=Brian D. |url=http://www.macleans.ca/authors/brian-d-johnson/mashing-up-copyright-in-rip-a-remix-manifesto |title=Mashing-up copyright in ‘RiP: A Remix Manifesto.’ |publisher=Maclean's |date=2008-12-08 |accessdate=2014-06-19}} Showing at the [[Whistler Film Festival]], that took place 4 to 7 December 2008,{{cite web |url=http://www.iofilm.co.uk/fm/r/rip_a_remix_manifesto_2008.shtml |title="iofilm review of RiP!: A Remix Manifesto" |date= |accessdate=2014-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601065848/http://www.iofilm.co.uk/fm/r/rip_a_remix_manifesto_2008.shtml |archivedate=1 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }} it also won the Cadillac People's Choice Award. It also received the Audience Choice award at the Ann Arbor Film Festival. At the [[Festival du Nouveau Cinéma]] in Montreal it won the Special Jury Prize. It was the closing film at [[Docs Barcelona]]. It was an honorable mention at the EBS film festival (Korea). It was the opening film of the Ambulante Film Festival (Mexico City). It was a Selection at the [[South by Southwest]] Film Festival, at [[Les Rendez-vous du cinéma québécois]], the [[Adelaide Film Festival]], Thessaloniki Film Festival, Silverdocs, [[Nashville Film Festival]], [[Victoria International Film Festival]], Yamagata International Documentary Festival, Planete Doc (Poland), [[Available Light Film Festival]], [[Buenos Aires Film Festival]], [[Sheffield Doc/Fest]] and the [[Munich Dokfest]], the [[New Zealand International Film Festivals]], Guth Gaga Film Festival (Ireland), and the International Film Festival of Rio. The film was in the running for Best Feature Length Documentary in the 30th Annual [[Genie Awards]] in Canada.{{cite web|last=Do |first=Anh Khoi |url=http://anhkhoi.blogspot.com/2010/04/winners-at-30th-genie-awards.html |title=Winners at the 30th Genie Awards |website=The Cultural Post |date=12 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-05-19}} == Broadcast == Documentary (Canada), Documentary Channel (USA), NHK (Japan), SBS (Australia), YLE (Finland), NRK (Norway), EBS (Korea), Canal D – Quebec, Yes – Israel, VPRO – Netherlands, TV3 – Catalonia, TVP Cultura – Poland, Globo – Brazil, Cult – Italy, Planete- France, iSat – Argentina + South America ==Reception== ''RiP!: A Remix Manifesto'' received mixed reviews from critics; The Globe and Mail called the film "A forceful, vibrant and immensely entertaining call to action." Critics in Australia in particular struggled with the polemical nature of the film. Many of the reviewers on the [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]] struggled with the director's point of film and the film received a 40% approval rating from critics there, with an average score of 5/10, based on 10 reviews. Audiences, meanwhile, gave the film a 75% approval rating based on 316 reviews.{{rotten-tomatoes|id=rip_a_remix_manifesto|title=RiP: A Remix Manifesto}} ==RiP!: A Remix Manifesto 2.0== On 27 February 2009 [[Brett Gaylor]] started a new project on his site, Open Source Cinema, dubbed RiP!: A Remix Manifesto 2.0. With this project, he invited users to take the original documentary, remix it, and upload their contributions to be included in a new, improved version of the film. The 2.0 was screened at the SilverDocs film festival. ==See also== * [[Copyleft]] * [[Open source movement]] * [[Public domain]] * ''[[Good Copy Bad Copy]]'' * ''[[Steal This Film]]'' * [[Girl Talk (musician)|Girl Talk]] * [[Lawrence Lessig]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=1397511|title=RiP!: A Remix Manifesto}} * ''[http://www.nfb.ca/film/rip_a_remix_manifesto/ RiP!: A Remix Manifesto]'' at the [[National Film Board of Canada]] * [http://www.eyesteelfilm.com EyeSteelFilm] * [https://vimeo.com/8040182 RiP!: A Remix Manifesto] on [[Vimeo]] * [http://vimeo.com/11749071 "Walking on Eggshells: Borrowing Culture in the Remix Age"] documentary {{EyeSteelFilm}} {{Intellectual property activism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rip!: A Remix Manifesto}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:EyeSteelFilm films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Canadian documentary films]] [[Category:National Film Board of Canada documentaries]] [[Category:Documentary films about the media]] [[Category:Open content]] [[Category:Open content films]] [[Category:Quebec films]] [[Category:Works about copyright law]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Films directed by Brett Gaylor]] [[Category:Creative_Commons-licensed_documentary_films]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = 'Sentimental Ballad' by Grant Wood, 1940.jpg | title = Sentimental Ballad | artist = [[Grant Wood]] | year = 1940 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on masonite]] | height_metric = 61 | width_metric = 127 | height_imperial = 24 | width_imperial = 50 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[New Britain, Connecticut]] | museum = [[New Britain Museum of American Art]] }} '''''Sentimental Ballad''''' is a 1940 painting by the American artist [[Grant Wood]]. It depicts a group of singing men in a bar.
The painting is located at the [[New Britain Museum of American Art]] in [[New Britain, Connecticut]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://arthistoryreference.com/cgi-bin/hd.exe?art2=a10870|title=Grant Wood. Sentimental Ballad|work=ArtHistortReference|accessdate=2016-12-06}}</ref>
==Creation== The painting came to be because of Wood's art dealer [[Associated American Artists]] and the film producer [[Walter Wanger]], who commissioned nine popular artists to paint a motif from the upcoming film ''[[The Long Voyage Home]]'', directed by [[John Ford]]. The other artists who participated were [[Thomas Hart Benton (painter)|Thomas Benton]], [[George Biddle]], [[James Ormsbee Chapin|James Chapin]], [[Ernest Fiene]], [[Robert Philipp]], Luis Quintanilla Isasi, [[Raphael Soyer]] and Georges Schreiber. The artists visited the set of the film for several weeks in May 1940. Wood's scene is toward the end of the film and features, from left to right, the actors [[John Qualen]], [[John Wayne]], [[Barry Fitzgerald]], [[Thomas Mitchell (actor)|Thomas Mitchell]], [[Joe Sawyer]], David Hughes and [[Jack Pennick]].<ref name="nbmaa">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbmaa.org/original-site-assets/timeline_highlights/essays/wood.html|title=''Sentimental Ballad'', 1940|publisher=[[New Britain Museum of American Art]]|accessdate=2016-12-06}}</ref>
==Reception== Although originally commissioned for the marketing of a film, the painting was well received in the press and went on to tour American museums.<ref name="nbmaa" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Sonya Levien | birth_date = {{birth date|1888|12|25|df=yes}} | birth_place = Russia | death_date = {{death date and age|1960|3|19|1888|12|25|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Hollywood, California]], USA | othername = Sonya Hovey | occupation = Screenwriter | spouses = [[Carl Hovey]] (?-1956) | yearsactive = 1921–1962 }} '''Sonya Levien''' (born '''Sara Opesken'''; 25 December 1888 – 19 March 1960) was a Russian-born American screenwriter. She became one of the highest earning female screenwriters in Hollywood in the 1930s and would help a number of directors and film stars transition from silent films to talkies. In 1955 she received an Academy Award for her screenplay ''[[Interrupted Melody]].''
== Early life == Sara Opesken (Sonya being the Russian diminutive)<ref name=":04"/> was born in Panimunik, a small village in the [[Pale of Settlement]] on 25 December 1888 (later changing the date to 1898.)<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=1}}</ref> The oldest child to parents Julius (b. ca. 1863) and Fanny (b.ca. 1865),<ref name=":0" /> Sonya had two brothers, Arnold and Max.<ref name="jwa.org">{{Cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/levien-sonya|title=Sonya Levien {{!}} Jewish Women's Archive|website=jwa.org|access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref>
During this period, Russian authorities kept a watchful eye over citizens, especially [[Jews|Jewish]] people with radical affiliations.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: : A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=4}}</ref> Sonya's father had a remote connection with a radical newspaper as well as agreeing with the anarchist ideas of Prince [[Peter Kropotkin]].<ref name=":1" /> Julius Opesken also joined a [[Narodniks|Narodnik]] study circle before being arrested and put to work in the [[Siberia]]n mines. While their father served his time, the Opesken family moved in with Julius' father, a [[rabbi]], who stressed the importance of language to a young Sonya.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: : A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=5}}</ref> Her grandfather instructed her in Russian, French, German, and [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] as well as encouraged her to read from the [[Talmud]] and the [[Shulchan Aruch|Shulhan' Aruk]] on a daily basis.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: : A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=6}}</ref>
In 1891, her father escaped exile and made his way to America, choosing to take on the surname of his German rescuer, Levien. He brought the rest of his family over in 1896, where they joined him on the [[Lower East Side|Lower East Side of Manhattan]].<ref name=":2" /> They were not the only Russian Jews between 1891 and 1900, in these nine years over 150,000 Jews came to [[New York City|New York]] alone.<ref name=":2" /> Once settled in America, her parents had two more sons, Edward and Nathan.<ref name="jwa.org"/> The family received their naturalization papers in 1905.<ref name=":2" />
All of the children in her family worked through school to help with expenses. Sonya worked in a feather-duster factory throughout her teenage years, making four dollars each week.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: : A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=8}}</ref> During her formative years in America, having grown up in poverty, she joined a group of [[Socialism|socialists]].<ref name=":3" /> Sonya, like many other European immigrants in America, went to a public grammar school. After she finished in 1901 or 1902, she was unable to continue to high school due to financial issues.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=9}}</ref> She took out a loan for $36 in order to learn [[stenography]] and get a job as a secretary. It took her four years of work to repay this loan. During her time as a secretary she also became acquainted with [[Settlement movement|settlement]] work and [[Trade union|labor unions]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=10}}</ref> Sonya also managed to take some classes at the [[The Educational Alliance|Educational Alliance]] where, in 1903, she met [[Rose Pastor Stokes|Rose Pastor]]. Not only did Pastor hire her as a secretary, she was also a member of the [[Socialist Party]] and the [[Women's Trade Union League]], giving Sonya access to a whole library of texts on these subjects she could read.<ref name=":4" />
Levien began to write her own work by sending in short comedic squibs to [[Life (magazine)|Life]] and with these earnings was able to contribute to her college tuition and her family's well being.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=11}}</ref> By fall 1906, she enrolled at [[New York University School of Law|New York University Law School]] for a Certificate of Law, seeing it as a more practical job option than writing,<ref name="jwa.org"/> however she still wrote short scenes for productions at her university.<ref name=":5" /> Just a year later, she was hired as a secretary to the editor of ''Success'', [[Samuel Merwin (writer)|Samuel Merwin]]. Here, her duties began to span more than secretary jurisdiction. She also read manuscripts, rewrote articles, sometimes even collaborated with an author.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=12–13}}</ref>
In 1909, she went for admission to the [[New York State Bar Association]], but discovered she was too sympathetic in character to work in a court of law. Instead she chose her work at ''Success'' and received a promotion to fiction reader.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=14–15}}</ref> ''Success'' had its last publication in December 1911 and Levien's next employment came from [[Woman's Journal|The Woman's Journal]], a publication interested in the [[National Woman Suffrage Association|women's suffrage movement]].<ref name=":6" /> She worked there in 1912 as an assistant editor and business manager.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosenbloom|first=Nancy J.|date=2015|title=From Greenwich Village to Hollywood: The Literary Apprenticeship OF Sonya Levien|url=|journal=The Journal of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era|doi=10.1017/S1537781414000577|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Towards the end of 1912 she sent a short story to Carl Hovey, who was a co-editor at the time, and began work at [[The Metropolitan Magazine|The Metropolitan]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrows Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=16–17}}</ref>
Having retained a connection with her roots, Sonya helped out at the [[People's Institute]], an organization which helped supply immigrants with the skills they might need to join the workforce in America.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Cepalir|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=22}}</ref> She also worked on the [[National Board of Review|National Board of Censorship]] as an Educational Secretary.<ref name=":02" /> However, when [[World War I]] commenced, Levien was working in London covering the British [[Women's suffrage|Suffragist]] movement for fourteen months <ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=23}}</ref> in 1913 and 1914.<ref name="jwa.org"/> Here she wrote editorials urging women to demand for more than just suffrage and ask for school, as well as institutional, reform and better living conditions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=24}}</ref>
== Career == Sonya returned to America in 1914 and focused her creative efforts on writing. She sent stories to a number of publications including ''[[The Saturday Evening Post|Saturday Evening Post]], [[Collier's|Collier’s]], [[Redbook]], [[Ladies' Home Journal|Ladies Home Journal]], Harpers, [[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]], [[The Atlantic|Atlantic Monthly]],'' and ''Century''.<ref name=":13"/> She then moved onto writing [[melodrama]]s, although her success in this endeavor was not immediate. In 1919 she received her first credit for an original story, the film ''Who Will Marry Me?'' <ref name="jwa.org"/> Her second credit came in 1921, and incidentally ''Cheated Love'' followed a Jewish immigrant, named Sonya who is in love with a doctor above her social standing. She did additional story on this project.<ref name=":03">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=54}}</ref>
By the end of 1921, [[Famous Players-Lasky]] bought two of her stories "The Heart of Youth" and "Baby Doll" paying her $2500 and $3000 respectively. Feedback for Baby Doll was mixed, but was eventually made into the film ''[[The Top of New York]].'' These stories gave Sonya the opportunity of a contract: she would receive $24,000 her first year there and receive a raise of $5000 each year for five consequent years. This led her to move west, to Hollywood, leaving her family behind in New York.<ref name=":03" /> She worked tirelessly and received three Hollywood credits for ''The Snow Bride, Pink Gods,'' and ''The Exciters.''<ref name=":03" />
Yet, by 1923, she missed her young son Serge and felt she had the duty to support her husband's career over her own, so she broke her contract by Famous Players-Lasky and returned to her family.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=55}}</ref> Here she received an editorial position at ''[[McClure's|McClure's Magazine]]''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=56}}</ref> Shortly after, in fall of 1924, Famous Players-Lasky requested she adapt a novel, ''[[Salome of the Tenements]]'', for the screen, the story of which actually paralleled Sonya's own life story. She made a great many changes to the plot, however reviews for the film highlighted the directing and not the script work.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=61}}</ref> Next, she did scenario editing work at Samuel Goldwyn Pictures. For this job, she attended Broadway plays and would find ways to adapt them into films.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=64}}</ref> By this time, her husband's editing work had ended and they decided to move together this time to Hollywood. He would edit stories for [[Cecil B. DeMille|C.B. DeMille]] and Sonya would write scenarios. Unfortunately Carl would not do so well in Hollywood, unable to find another job after DeMille. Sonya found herself with regular work and as the main breadwinner in the family.<ref name=":12" /> Not only did she write for film, but she also continued as an author for magazines and even tried her hand at plays, such as the one-act "By the Sword" which was performed by The Writer's Club.<ref name=":22">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=66}}</ref>
Despite being a woman, Sonya managed to avoid being categorized as someone who wrote only films for women. She was experienced in all genres (null Western or Gangster films.) Her forte came in adapting outside material for film.<ref name=":22" /> She worked her first four years back in [[Hollywood]] with the name Sonya Hovey for a number of different studios.<ref name=":22" /> She worked for [[Warner Bros.]] from January to June 1926. Here, she wrote her first comedy, a move from her usual melodramas. ''[[Footloose Widows]]'' featured mistaken identities, mix ups between poor and wealthy people, and even gold digging- all elements of the screwball comedy genre.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=67}}</ref>
She was hired by C.B. DeMille in August 1926 for [[Metropolitan Pictures]] and [[Pathé]]. She worked for him until June 1928 and during this time experimented in genre. In autumn, she signed with [[Columbia Pictures]], where she wrote a number of features until March 1929.<ref name=":32">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=69–70}}</ref> She was elected to the board of The Writer's Club and in May 1929 was offered a contract at [[Fox Film|Fox Film Corp]]. She would stay with them until 1939.<ref name=":32" /> Her first yearly contract supplied her with $500/ week, and after the first six months she received $600/ week. One year renewal options granted her $750. But although her pay was good, legally she was not able to receive screen credit or publicity for each project she contributed to. She had to pay to advertise her own name.<ref name=":42">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=72}}</ref> Nonetheless, Sonya became one of the top writers which allowed her to work alongside big stars and well-known directors. In the years 1929-1935, she would work on an estimated six screenplays a year, receiving about five credits.<ref name=":42" /> During this period, she was able to write four films for [[Charles Farrell]] and [[Janet Gaynor]], two more for Janet Gaynor, five for [[Will Rogers]], and have a total of six of her stories directed by [[Frank Borzage]]. She also worked with directors [[Allan Dwan]] and [[John Ford]]. Although uncredited, she made additions for [[Shirley Temple]] in ''[[Curly Top (film)|Curly Top]].'' <ref name=":42" />
Sonya garnered a reputation for being able to adapt all kinds of material into a film screenplay, although she was not known for her prowess at dialogue.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=74}}</ref> For Fox, she penned a detective thriller ''[[Behind That Curtain (film)|Behind that Curtain]]'', featuring [[Charlie Chan]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=75}}</ref> She worked at length with [[Frank Borzage]] on ''Lucky Star,'' only to have it be labelled Frank Borzage's ''Lucky Star.'' Sonya helped not only Borzage, but also [[Will Rogers]], transition to sound films.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=76}}</ref> She also collaborated with [[S. N. Behrman|S.N. Behrman]] in three of the next six projects she would assist on.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=77}}</ref>
Levien was Fox’s highest paid female screenwriter during the 1930s.<ref name="Rosenbloom 2015">{{Cite journal|last=Rosenbloom|first=Nancy J.|date=2015|title=From Greenwich Village to Hollywood: The Literary Apprenticeship of Soya Levien|url=|journal=The Journal of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era|doi=10.1017/S1537781414000577|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Her films were also known for dealing with family conflicts.<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Screenwriters: Second Series|last=Hurwitz|first=Edith|publisher=Gale Research Company|year=1986|isbn=|location=|pages=177}}</ref> In 1933, still employed by Fox Studios, Sonya would receive an [[Oscar nominations|Oscar nomination]] for ''[[State Fair (1945 film)|State Fair]].'' <ref name=":52">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/99491/Sonya-Levien/biography|title=The New York Times|last=Hal Erickson|first=Rovi|date=2010|website=The New York Times|publisher=Baseline|access-date=9 March 2016}}</ref> She penned John Ford's first [[Technicolor]] film in 1939, ''[[Drums Along the Mohawk]].'' <ref name=":52" /> She also worked for RKO, working on ''Hunchback of Notre Dame'' in 1939 as well.
She then went on to sign a contract with [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]] in 1941.<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Screenwriters: Second Series|last=Hurwitz|first=Edith|publisher=Gale Research Company|year=1986|isbn=|location=|pages=176}}</ref> By 1955, she had won an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for ''[[Interrupted Melody]]'' for MGM.<ref name=":52" /> Sonya garnered an impressive filmography, having worked on over 70 films spanning her career, a great deal of the time without a collaborator.<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Screenwriters: Second Series|last=Hurwitz|first=Edith|publisher=Gale Research Company|year=1986|isbn=|location=|pages=173}}</ref> In fact, she was presented with the first Laurel Award presented from the Screenwriters Guild of America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-sonya-levien/|title=Sonya Levien – Women Film Pioneers Project|website=wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu|access-date=25 February 2016}}</ref> Her last screen credits included ''[[Jeanne Eagels (film)|Jeanne Eagels]]'' from 1957<ref name=":62">{{Cite web|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-sonya-levien/|title=Sonya Levien Profile|last=Brett Erans|first=Patricia|date=27 September 2013|website=Women Film Pioneers Project|publisher=Columbia University Libraries|access-date=9 March 2016}}</ref> and in 1960, she would receive her final screen credit for Pepe.<ref name=":52" />
== Personal life == Levien married her husband Carl Hovey on 11 October 1917.<ref name=":04">{{Cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/levien-sonya|title=Sonya Levien|last=Levy-Reiner|first=Sherry|date=2009|website=Jewish Women: A Comprehensive Historical Encyclopedia|publisher=Jewish Women's Archive|access-date=8 March 2016}}</ref> They moved together to East 92nd street in [[New York City|New York]], and Sonya took in Hovey's two children from his previous marriage.<ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=29}}</ref> Hovey was an [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] [[Protestantism|Protestant]]<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=28}}</ref> but they had little protest from either of their families <ref name=":04" /> and even decided to declare their own children Jewish, although they would not enforce a religious upbringing on them.<ref name=":13" /> Together they had two children: a son, Serge (b. 1920) and a daughter, Tamara (b. 1923.) <ref name=":04" /> Although Levien has stated that her instincts told her she should have six or seven children, she found that a large family would take years away from her career and was not financially suitable for her.<ref name=":12"/> In fact, her husband failed to find steady employment once they moved to Hollywood together and she bore the responsibility of supporting him, their children, his two children from a previous marriage, as well as making a comfortable home for them.<ref name=":22"/>
Levien has described herself as one who enjoys music, singing and playing the piano, as well as reading biographies. Although she admired nice clothing, she usually wore sports clothes and hated going shopping. Sonya generally avoided confrontation and arguments with her acquaintances, and shied away from talking on the telephone. She self-identified as ambitious, but also restless in character.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Great Lady: A Life of the Screenwriter Sonya Levien|last=Ceplair|first=Larry|publisher=Scarecrow Publishing|year=1996|isbn=|location=Lanham|pages=73}}</ref> Those she worked with stated that Levien was easy to work with and would help out others often.<ref name="Rosenbloom 2015"/> Her husband died in 1956 and she developed [[cancer]] in the mid 1950s. Sonya Levien died on 19 March 1960 at the age of 71.<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Screenwriters: Second Series|last=Hurwitz|first=Edith|publisher=Gale Research Company|year=1986|isbn=|location=|pages=178}}</ref>
== Politics == Levien was a [[Secular jewish culture|Secular Jew]] who was very interested in activism in her early years, living on the East Side of New York. She describes her natural pull to more radical views, joining a group of agitators formed majorly of socialists but which also included [[Anarchism|anarchists]] and [[single-taxers]]. Levien was known for supporting the [[suffragette]] cause in the early 20th century. Both in her film and non-film works, Levien wrote about the struggles of immigrant women and families. Levien belonged to the [[Heterodoxy (group)|Heterodoxy]] club, which was a debate group focusing on radical feminism. She also heavily supported [[Women's emancipation|women’s emancipation]] and [[birth control]]. Many of the films in the beginnings of her career focused on Jewish people, however many of her female characters found their happiness in [[Marriage|wedlock]], and signs of her own radical sensibilities were not always apparent in her film work. Once in Hollywood she was known as an [[Apoliticism|apolitical]] woman. In fact, shortly after 1950, her daughter Tamara and her husband, Lee Gold, were blacklisted as members of the [[Communist party|Communist Party]], Sonya chose never to comment publicly.
